events.name: The Spring Portlet MVC, by Henok Wondem
events.description:
Henok Wondem will be walking through a few scenarios invoking some of the many API's in the Spring framework, among them the Spring Portlet MVC.

We'll have free food -- probably Jet's Pizza, unless someone requests otherwise.  RSVP with your preferences (e.g., "But I wanted sushi!" or "Vegan only please.").
events.how_to_find_us: Enter the BMI Lobby, then take the elevator to the second floor.  A security guard might ask where you're going, but one of us should be around to let you upstairs.

events.name: Android Homescreen Widgets, by Zach McCormick
events.description: Zach will take us on a walkthrough of the anatomy of an Android homescreen widget then show some examples of their use in state of the art applications.

events.name: Nashville Joint User Group EoY Party!
events.description:
You are invited to join with developers from around Nashville for an evening of networking and noise making. Members of the various local User Groups will gather together, talk shop, lift a glass, and celebrate the season. See old friends and explain to them why you've not been to the last few meetings or just find out about the other groups in the area.

PLEASE CLICK HERE TO R.S.V.P. ON EVENTBRITE INSTEAD OF MEETUP - this is a group party and the organizers will have no visibility to RSVPs left here. 

Hope to see you there!

events.name: GDG Music City presents: Google Glass
events.description: Several of our members recently joined the Glass explorer program. We're going to share our experiences such as UI/UX implementation, social reception, durability, and programming as well as showcase photos and videos we've taken while out and about. Everyone will have an opportunity to try a pair for themselves so come on out and experience this exciting new form factor!

events.name: Android Unit Testing, by Zach McCormick + Google Glass, civic development, pizza
events.description:
Zach McCormick will discuss a unit testing paradigm that he has put together at his organization which employs Robolectric, RoboGuice, Mockit, and Cucumber.  This system allows them to unit test most their Android code and simultaneously perform acceptance testing and user story validation.  The project architecture that Zach will discuss outlines a useful archetype for starting industry-strength projects.

We'll also open up the meeting after Zach's presentation for attendee participation -- as in an open meeting.  If you've been working on something cool that you think is worth sharing, come ready to talk informally about it.  We'd like to hear what's going on in the community, and we'll be fishing for ideas for upcoming meetups.

Yiaway Yeh from the Nashville Mayor's office will discuss the 2014 Multi-City Innovation Campaign, an opportunity for local developers to participate in the assembly of apps using civic and government data.

Also, because a couple of the members of this group are Google Glass Explorers, we're letting anyone who attends try them out.

Did we mention there'll be pizza?   Come hungry.   Bring a friend!
events.how_to_find_us: BMI is in the block enclosed by Music Square E, Division St., Music Circle E, and Music Circle N.  You can park on Music Circle North or in the guest parking lot on that street, across from the SAE Institute of Technology.

events.name: ***VIRTUAL MEETUP*** 2014 Multi-City  Innovation Campaign Orientation Session
events.description:
This is a VIRTUAL EVENT ONLY and will take place here via Google Hangouts (a plugin is required). Hangouts is limited to 10 people only so please buddy up if possible. 

The goal of this session is to generate ideas then have people form independent teams if they find an idea they would like to work on.  NMDUG is hosting this Hangout as an opportunity for people to connect quickly, as the submission deadline is fast approaching - March 14.

Here is more information on the campaign. The quick version is that  Boston, Palo Alto, and Raleigh are partnering up with Nashville to inspire the next version of civic apps and are calling on developers to submit solutions that are relevant to each city. Datasets from the city will be available to developers.

We'll see how much response we get to this - if it's clear more than 10 people are interested we'll figure something out.

events.name: Google Cloud Platform Video Preview
events.description:
We will be discussing the upcoming Google Cloud Platform Live Event, previewing the highlight video, and considering the possiblities for upcoming GDG Music City events.

Archived video from the event:

http://youtu.be/hTyqTnZtZlg

events.name: Google Chromecast Hacking
events.description:
Kris Ray will discuss the development of a solution for casting content to the big screen, using the Google Cast SDK.

Following, we will have an open discussion of the Google Cloud Event, which may still be ongoing at the time of our meetup.

Also, of course, we'll have food.  Come hungry!

Archived hangout recording:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GlhtIBZAE3M&feature=youtu.be
events.how_to_find_us: BMI is in the block enclosed by Music Square E, Division St., Music Circle E, and Music Circle N.  You can park on Music Circle North or in the guest parking lot on that street, across from the SAE Institute of Technology.

events.name: Responsive Design, by Colin Lord
events.description:
The first time I tried to code out a fully responsive site felt a lot like the first time I tried to run a 10k: it just made me tired and angry. But now? I love running and I can’t imagine building a large site that isn’t responsive.

I’ll be discussing responsive development: what it is, why it’s better than a separate mobile site, why it should be approached differently than a native app, and best practices that I’ve found. We’ll be looking at a couple live sites I’ve built so if you want to follow along, bring your smartphone and/or tablet.

events.name: Functional Tests for iOS, by Lauren O'Meara
events.description: Sometimes it is hard to know where/how to get started with testing. For iOS, there are many different tools and approaches available. Apple offers a great JavaScript solution with recorder that you can use to create a testing system fairly quickly. This talk will demonstrate some of Apple's tools starting with using the recorder to add an initial test to an existing project and building up a library and suite of tests.

events.name: Google I/O Extended Nashville 2014
events.description:
GDG Music City invites you to the 2014 Google I/O Extended Nashville event kindly hosted by Mercury Intermedia. The event will begin with the keynote live streaming from San Francisco followed by other sessions throughout the day. We'd love to have a powered by Google show and tell so come show off any Google tech you've been working on! Food will be available and prizes will be given at random.﻿

Update on prizes from Google:

• 2 Android Wear devices

• 1 Nexus 7, 32 GB

• 1 Nexus 5, 32 GB

• 6 Chromecast devices

https://plus.google.com/events/c19fs8p5uq35dt78jaukotogbqc

events.name: GWT, by Joseph Banta
events.description:
In July's meetup, Joseph Banta will review an approach for assembling a web app using the Google Web Toolkit (GWT).  The GWT provides a mechanism for developers to implement the user-interface and back-end logic all in java, with the client-side code compiling down to dynamic javascript-driven HTML.  Joseph will go over some of the basics of interacting with the GWT, and will review a couple of complete applications that are driven by the framework.

The event will be recorded via Google+ Hangout On Air and will be viewable via youtube:

• https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EZ1ZDMj_2GY

events.name: Swift, by Mike Simmons
events.description:
Mike Simmons, a Technology Delivery Manager and iOS developer at BMI, will talk about Swift, the new programming language from Apple. Swift builds upon C and Objective-C as well as a number of other languages, emphasizing safety, clean code, and a modern syntax. Mike will talk about how Swift differs from Objective-C and cover some of the new features it introduces, as well as give a demo or two.

Mike’s career has spanned punched cards to the present. He has developed embedded realtime control systems, cell phone firmware, server-based audio recording applications, and more. He first learned Objective-C in 1992 on the NeXT computer and never looked back.

events.name: Show Your Stuff, by you
events.description:
For our penultimate 2014 meetup we'd like to see what you're up to, mobile or not. Been working on a cool project? Show it off! Working on a difficult problem and want to get a different perspective? That's what this is for. Have news you'd like to share with the community? This is your time.

We'll also have Google hardware demos so you can check out Android Wear, Android TV, Cardboard, and Glass.

events.name: Android vs. iPhone Cage Match!
events.description:
Ever witness a discussion over which phone is better? Sometimes they can get ugly! For our final meeting of 2014 we want to put two teams together for a d̶e̶a̶t̶h̶m̶a̶t̶c̶h̶  panel discussion and ask questions regarding development experience, state of the ecosystem, perception about the other's platform etc...

Hopefully everyone will learn something that they can use -  both platforms will have released major upgrades to their OS in 2014 so it's a great time to check out what's going on in both worlds and have an opportunity to compare/contrast with each other.

We'd love to have some audience participation - you can submit your own questions here and nominate someone for the panel here.

events.name: Android Development for Experienced Programmers
events.description:
In our January meetup, we'll discuss an online certification program that Google has agreed to sponsor for our members:  the Udacity 'Developing Android Apps' course.

In February and March, we'll be hosting a series of weekly meetups in which participating members can learn Android development from the ground up.  Google is graciously sponsoring anyone who signs up through the group to take the course, which rewards certificates and "nano-degrees" to students that fulfill the course requirements.  Obviously this would be a good resume-builder for anyone starting out, and a decent refresher course for even seasoned developers.

One of the group's organizers, Joseph Banta, has completed the course himself, and will be on-hand to facilitate the weekly meetups surrounding the course.  Our January meetup will focus on Joseph's experience with the course, and the merits that it could provide.

Additionally, we will be discussing plans for group for the upcoming year.  Of course, we'll also have (FREE) food and drink!

The actual study group meetup:
http://www.meetup.com/NashvilleMDUG/events/219315913/
events.how_to_find_us: Street parking is available along Music Circle North, or in the guest parking lot off of Music Circle North.

events.name: The Status of Nashville in Technology, with Yiaway Yeh
events.description:
Yiaway Yeh of the Nashville Mayor's office will speak on current and upcoming developments in the tech realm in Nashville and the city's ongoing efforts to promote innovation, including info on the rollout of Google Fiber.

With an increasing level of enterprise participation in the build-out of IT infrastructure, including commitments by AT&T, Comcast, and Google, Nashville is imminently becoming a global hub of technology. With this expanded bandwidth, we in Nashville will be capable of great things, and will be tasked with charting the future of our region. Along the way, we will have to overcome many obstacles, and answer many questions. Where is Nashville going? What kinds of things can we expect -- what solutions can we build -- when network latency is a thing of the past? Who will provide the technical leadership that will guide our companies in this more complicated world?

Yiaway will deliver a brief talk on these and other issues, and will take time to answer questions from the community afterwards.

Yiaway is the Co-Chief Innovation Officer with the Metro Government of Nashville & Davidson County, and is the former Mayor and City Councilmember of Palo Alto, California.  Mr. Yeh moved to Nashville, Tennessee following his wife joining the faculty of the Department of Political Science at Vanderbilt University.  He was appointed by Mayor Karl Dean of Nashville to head up the new Mayor's Office of Innovation announced on April 26, 2013.

events.name: Android Fundamentals Study Group: Final Project Polishing
events.description:
A couple of the Android Study group participants would like to get back together to work through issues.  We'll take this time to polish up our projects in preparation for submission to Udacity, and perhaps to find those extra elements of "Udaciousness" that would be quick tick-offs for our respective apps.

Also, we're considering putting demos of the study group final project apps on the schedule for our I/O Extended event happening on Thursday, May 28.  Note that that event will be in the middle of a work day, but you are welcome to come to only select parts.  We'll probably have some kind of "Thank you" gift for those wanting to present.

Remember, if you need help getting your app working, you should be able to find others in the group on the Slack "nmdug" team.  If you didn't get an invite, please email [masked], and Joseph will add you to the team.

events.name: New Android Feature (???) -- Viewing Party & Hackathon
events.description:
On June 5 an as yet unannounced feature will be released for Android devices. Google will present a video stream including engineers at Google and some past I/O keynote speakers.

***Update*** We have unofficial confirmation that the feature of focus here is in Android M, the latest Android version announced during the I/O Keynote.  If you plan on participating in the hackable portion of this event, it will expedite things for you if you have the Android SDK for Android M preinstalled.

Google has invited our group to host a viewing/hack party, where participants will be the first to see the feature and will work through issues and identify bugs.

Prizes will be awarded by Google for the best reported bug and for best overall feedback, including Nexus 6 devices.

https://events.withgoogle.com/whats-new-in-android-hackhome/

What do I need to be part of this event? It's simple:

• Computer with a working Android M development environment.

• Internet connection that can handle streamed video.

• Your existing Android app, if you have one.

• A Google+ account, if you want to ask questions.

What does this event look like?

You will be able to connect to a live video stream. Google's Android experts, Chet Haase, Dan Sandler, Adam Powell, will start with a short introduction about what's new in Android. Then you will be able to submit your questions on Google+. The experts will pick questions and answer them in the video stream.

events.name: Google Project Tango: Virtual Reality Comes to the Consumer
events.description:
The buzz has been building about Google's Project Tango.  As of now, this project takes the shape of a tablet-sized device that is capable of constructing a three-dimensional model of its environment in real time, and presenting it in a 3D viewer on the device.  It is also a simple matter to assemble an application that tracks the user's location in space with 6 degrees of articulation.

The Project Tango has a horrible name, but is a neat piece of technology.  We'll be showing off some of the apps that have already been written for it, and capturing a 3-D area map (essentially a 3-D picture) during the meeting.

Our own Joseph Banta recently had a chance to participate in a hackathon focused on making apps for the motion-tracking device.  He'll talk about his experience at that hackathon, and review the current state of the technology.

Also as part of the presentation, Joseph will walk through a code lab for the Google Cardboard.  If you have a cardboard, bring it.  We'll have a couple of our own, but probably not enough for everybody (we already gave them away!).  This code lab is for ANYONE -- no coding skills are necessary.  Essentially we'll be building a Unity app and targetting it to your Android phone.  That means when you walk out, you'll know the basics for putting together a 3-D world in Unity and making it work on your phone.  So the prerequisites for the code lab will be 

• Your computer

• Your Android phone

• Your Google Cardboard

If possible, you should install Unity on your computer beforehand.  Follow this link to download Unity.

The code lab will hopefully fun for spectators too -- we'll end up with a functional game!  At the end of the night we plan to raffle off a Syma X5C HD Quadcopter, so also bring your rabbit's foot or talisman of choice.

See you then.

P.S.  No rabbits were harmed during the composition of this meeting summary.

events.name: Backing your app with Firebase
events.description:
Firebase is a platform that can handle your app's backend, data storage, user auth, static hosting, and offline support concerns. It's also extremely simple to implement.

In this meeting we'll walkthrough the Going Places with Android codelab from this year's I/O, which implements Firebase and the Google Places API. We'll then take a closer look at what the Firebase API has to offer.

The lab uses Android Studio to quickly scaffold a Google Maps Activity, so please install Android Studio before the meetup if you wish to follow along; our wifi may not be able to support multiple people trying to install on the spot.

events.name: BLE, iBeacon, Eddystone and the Physical Web
events.description:
This month we're happy to have Beat Zenerino of BKON and Bitvana come talk about Bluetooth LE, iBeacons, Eddystone, and the Physical Web!

First, he will introduce a high-level overview of the Bluetooth Smart protocol including services and characteristics. He will also go over how two devices discover each other and subsequently connect. With this knowledge, he will then cover how iBeacon and Eddystone utilize this protocol to provide location based services. he will touch on the differences between CoreBluetooth and CoreLocation in iOS and how the iBeacon protocol uses these libraries. Then he will conclude his presentation with a code walkthrough on how to use the Bluetooth LE Sample code from Google to scan for beacons on Android.

Come prepared with Android Studio, Xcode, or both for some hands-on learning!

events.name: Google Project Tango: A Unity Primer
events.description:
To ensure that our hackathon participants can hit the ground running on Saturday morning, we're hosting a code lab that will get you started with a Unity project that targets and runs on the Tango device.

This event is complementary to the hackathon, and IS COMPLETELY OPTIONAL.  The point is to get folks started with Unity, so that there's not so much of a learning curve on Saturday morning.  We'll walk through a Google-supplied Tango code lab, and you should have a working Tango app by the time we're done.

Unity experts are welcome.  The organizer of this meeting, Joseph Banta, has only basic Unity experience, and would welcome the expertise of experienced developers.

This meetup is scheduled at J & J's Market for now instead of the hackathon venue (emma) because there is a street festival scheduled near emma this evening that could make parking difficult.

events.name: Google Project Tango Hackathon
events.description:
The buzz has been building about Google's Project Tango.  As of now, this project takes the shape of a tablet-sized Android device that is capable of constructing a three-dimensional model of its environment in real time, and presenting a 3D view of the reconstructed model on the device.  An application can also track the device's location in space as it moves around, with 6 degrees of articulation.  The Project Tango has a horrible name, but is a neat piece of technology.

Come with your hacker buddies and form a team, or be ready to work with other free agents to conceptualize and assemble an app prototype.  During this one-day hackathon, each team will implement its own idea for a Tango app, ending the day with a presentation of the product, finished or not!  Project apps can be built from scratch, or pre-existing apps can be targetted and rebuilt for the Tango during the hackathon.  The projects will be judged by our celebrity panel, and five project tango devices will be awarded to the winning team.  To compensate for the fact that some pre-built apps will obviously have more polish, apps built from scratch on the day of the event will receive extra points toward the end-of-day competition.  

All prospective participants should complete our APPLICATION<a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1zIJkK-uo91g5P6Wsk0T4TT0uj8HBzEpErmqM09hnVL0/viewform"></a> so that we can allocate teams and properly accommodate dietary restrictions.

Developers: Bring your computer for assembling an app which will target the Tango device.  Each team will be provided a Tango to use for development for the day.

The hackathon isn't just for coders -- teams will want designers, graphics artists, asset finders, and decision makers!  A team should be comprised of no more than 5 participants.

We'll have food for the entire day, so come hungry and plan to stay.  There will of course be SWAG for all, possibly including a Durovis Dive virtual reality headset.  We'll also have some ongoing distractions to keep everybody awake, perhaps including a live music jam!

See you then.

events.name: Mobile Development   CAGE   MATCH !!!
events.description:
In 2014 the Nashville Mobile Development User Group hosted our first annual epic Cage Match, pitting the two nastiest contenders, Android and iOS, against one another in a battle to the death.  Or, 7:30 PM -- whichever came first.

Unfortunately, the bell rang ending the bout before any death blows could be dealt, so this time, Android and iOS are on the same tag team: Native Mobile Development, set to battle their bitter enemies:  Mobile Web Development and Hybrid Mobile Development.

The purview of the Native team ought to be fairly obvious: these are guys who write native Android and iOS code for a living, and that's the paradigm they believe in.  The other teams may seem unfamiliar, but you see their products every day.  Mobile Web Development is the practice of building web content with an eye toward the mobile screen, considering responsive design principles.  The areas of expertise on this team encompass the entire pantheon of mobile web development including HTML5, JavaScript, web servers, and CDNs.

What do we mean by Hybrid Mobile Development?  This is the assembly of mobile apps employing a framework that bypasses the traditional mobile SDK's, typically allowing the developer to build for multiple mobile platforms from a single codebase.  This includes a vast range of development paradigms, ranging from popular toolsets like Xamarin and Titanium to such established and controversial libraries as Phonegap or React.  We can't possibly represent all of these fields of expertise, so we'll limit it to a couple of developers who are passionate champions of their chosen framework.

These three teams will answer our questions in a public forum, with a central moderator posing talking points and restraining the bloodthirsty opponents when necessary.

You can nominate panel members with this form and submit your own questions here.

The meetup will be recorded via Google hangout and archived on youtube at:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xprt2ab0F8Y

In our Study Group sessions, we will walk through the steps to create a functional Android app.  2015's Study Group was a great success, and 12 programmers with little or no Android programming experience got through the 6-session course and submitted their final projects for certification by Google and Udacity.  This year we aim to have at least as many complete the course.

2016's project is a lot simpler to complete than last year's.  They apparently figured out that people didn't want to know how to make a complicated app -- just a simple one.  That's the premise for this course, so if there is sufficient interest we can follow this beginner's group up with one that targets more intricate functionality.

events.name: Progressive Web Apps
events.description:
Progressive Web Apps are experiences that combine the best of the web and the best of apps. As the user progressively builds a relationship with the App over time, it becomes more and more powerful -- behaving more and more like a native app.  A PWA can have an icon on the home screen, and can send push notifications.  It loads quickly, even on flaky networks, and presents a top-level, full screen experience.

A Progressive Web App Dev Summit was held in Amsterdam on June 20, where the movers and shakers in the field discussed standards and best practices, and introduced the concepts for those new to the technology. We'll watch a couple of the presentations from the summit [candidates: 1, 2, 3, 4], then jump in with a code lab and build a basic Progressive Web App. If time allows, we'll run a second more advanced code lab. Attendees interested in participating in the code labs should bring their laptops.

Because we're holding this meeting in cooperation with NashJS, we ask that you RSVP on their event site, so we have a single place to get a head count.

THERE WILL BE SWAG and a raffle. Details to come...

events.name: DRY Coding Principles, with Sarah Klinefelter
events.description:
When information is duplicated within a system, the possibility for error is introduced.  Every line of code that goes into an application must be maintained, and is a potential source of future bugs.  Duplication needlessly bloats the codebase, resulting in more opportunities for bugs and adding accidental complexity to the system. [1]

To avoid this duplication, programmers should follow the mantra:  Every piece of knowledge must have a single, unambiguous, authoritative representation within a system.  [2]  This is the DRY principle.  Don't Repeat Yourself.  When the DRY principle is applied successfully, a modification of any single element of a system does not require a change in other logically unrelated elements.  Additionally, elements that are logically related all change predictably and uniformly, and are thus kept in sync. [3]

In this meetup, Sarah Klinefelter will demonstrate how to write code that’s maintainable, readable, and easy to change.  We'll discuss core DRY principles such as abstraction, the rule of three, single responsibility / separation of concern, and SPOT (single point of truth).

events.name: React Native with Guy Lemon
events.description:
(map)

Guy Lemon will discuss React Native: what it is, how it works, and what you can do with it.

• a quick overview of what React is/does

• introduce React Native via a basic app

• demonstrate building / styling a component

• demonstrate debugging / testing workflow

• If there is time, add some HTTP / async to the mix.

React Native is a great cross-platform framework for building mobile apps.  It's distinct from other universal frameworks in that it employs native building blocks for UI and other core functionalities, as opposed to wrapping a web app with an embedded web view.  It's a mature, extensible framework, in production use at Facebook, Instagram, AirBNB, WalMart, and others.

We'll get together at 6, and after socializing over pizza (thanks, TekSystems!), we'll get to the presentation.  See you tonight!  Come hungry.

events.name: Kotlin on Android, with Sean Beach
events.description:
(map to BMI)

The Kotlin programming language is now a "first class" language for the Android platform, supported in the primary IDE, Android Studio.  Kotlin makes some things very easy, and some things are different -- in Kotlin, there are  no raw types, arrays in Kotlin are  invariant, and Kotlin does not have checked  exceptions.  The list of differences is actually vast, meaning that there will be a learning curve for developers migrating from other languages. Sean Beach will explain some of these differences, and will dive into the application development cycle in Kotlin.

events.name: Google Cloud Functions with Http Triggers, with Michael Watson
events.description:
Google Cloud Functions provide a very simple mechanism for standing up back-end operations for any application, without having to worry about all the ordinary provisioning concerns. Previous incarnations of the notion of 'microservices' have still required the developer to take care of all the traditional framework and server configuration concerns, but those worries might be a thing of the past.

Michael Watson will discuss the deployment of Google Cloud Functions (GCF) using HTTP triggers, manipulating firebase data, and handling the async manipulation of that firebase data. He'll review the basic setup for GCF in the Google console, show a basic firebase database, and then demonstrate a simple Android activity which invokes the operation.

https://firebase.google.com/docs/functions/use-cases

events.name: Machine Learning Crash Course
events.description:
[See this map for venue and parking info: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1QoWTfmca2wUb-kM71LmJVHHJe6E&usp=sharing]

Ever wanted to create a software solution for predicting the future price of a stock? Or read the contents of a hand-written note? Or implicitly parse a spoken request? Problems like these are very difficult to solve. Often a programmer cannot readily calculate the relationships and heuristics necessary to produce a valid solution.

Enter Machine Learning. With enough example data, an ML system can be constructed to reproduce proven behavior, and to extrapolate new behavior. And with some of the tools that are available today, it's getting easier to put together such solutions.

Joseph Banta will introduce some of these tools, and kick-start a series of meetups highlighting Machine Learning tutorials.

events.name: WebAuthn, with Clayton Davis
events.description:
Tired of having your passwords and personal information stolen on the Web? WebAuthn (Web Authentication) is a new open standard supported by Google, Microsoft, Facebook, Yubico, Auth0, and the W3C. WebAuthn is set to replace existing hardware-based tokens like TOTP and stored passwords with public-key authentication that is easy to use and very difficult to phish. Since deploying their Titan Security Key with FIDO2 and WebAuthn, Google has seen zero phishing attacks internally. With support recently landing in Android for biometric authenticators, and support in most desktop browsers, passwords may become obsolete sooner than you think. Come learn how to deploy this groundbreaking technology in your apps and websites.

events.name: Do-it-yourself AI, with Joseph Banta
events.description:
Artificial Intelligence is everywhere now, whether you know it or not. Every google search, every Alexa inquiry, apps that do things like OCR or facial recognition, or chatbots -- they all make use of AI to do the hard things like speech recognition, algorithm optimization, even process management.

Getting started with AI can be easy. You don't have to have a PhD or work with Big Data every day. There are actually kits available with all hardware and instructions in the box.

The AIY Vision Kit from Google lets you build your own intelligent camera that can see and recognize objects using machine learning. All of this fits in a handy little cardboard cube, powered by a Raspberry Pi.

Joseph Banta of Band of Coders Nashville will showcase some of the nifty things you can do without even having to think.

Oh, and we'll have food. Come hungry!
